Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the 
     HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=kvCcejplK_dO-7N8Qcs4fynly6A1xPm9LngAW3uTDPCzXbej

       Hi Jeff,

From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
> To get your oscillations, do you also need recurrence?

Of course you need recurrence.

For some theoretical explorations about the dynamics of
leaky integrators you can check:
On the Dynamics of Small Continuous-Time Recurrent Neural Networks by
R. Beer.
http://www.ifi.unizh.ch/ailab/teaching/NN2007/misc/Beer_CTRNNDynamics_1995.pdf

And for a classical example about evolving oscillating behaviors with
leaky integrators:
http://birg2.epfl.ch/publications/fulltext/ijspeert01.pdf
By A. J. Ijspeert.

Btw, about the current debate, I think that giving a sinusoid as one
of the input simplifies a lot the task.
More precisely :

 - an oscillating network has to be recurrent, that's a substantially
 larger search space than feed-forward networks ;

 - it's easy but not immediate to get a sinusoid using leaky
 integrators; as a consequence, you need first to obtain stable
 oscillating behaviors (and reward it using your fitness) before
 having a setup somehow similar to the sinusoid one.

 - using a sinusoid, the only knowledge to be found is the correct
 delays between each moto-neuron and the input sinusoid; it's easier
 than finding a robust oscillating pattern correctly linked to each
 moto-neuron.

But, using leaky integrators is more interesting because:
 - a network of leaky integrators is a "universal temporal
 approximator", so, theoretically, you could get oscillating but
 non-sinusoidal patterns (actually, it's a lot harder than evolving a
 sinusoidal pattern) ;

 - the properties of leaky integrators oscillators make possible to
 obtain non-linear oscillators, which have a lot of synchronization
 properties (more later);

 - you could create tunable oscillators that adapts the locomotion
  pattern with respect to the sensor data (see Ijspeert's paper).

Having worked a lot with leaky integrators for locomotion, I
think you should use non-linear oscillators instead of them. These
oscillators have most of the properties of synchronization of
biological oscillators and are simpler to use since they have all the
good properties from scratch.

For quadruped locomotion, you can read :

- Adaptive dynamic walking of a quadruped robot on irregular terrain
 by using neural system model
H Kimura, Y Fukuoka, Y Hada, K Takase - A]. IEEE/RSJ. Intelligent
Robots and Systems, 2000

with the videos on this page:
http://robotics.mech.kit.ac.jp/research/photo-movie-UEC-e.html (see
Tekken 2 & Tekken 4)
(note that this behavior is not evolved but it's neuron-based).

-  From Swimming to Walking with a Salamander Robot Driven by a Spinal
  Cord Model
  AJ Ijspeert, A Crespi, D Ryczko, JM Cabelguen - Science, 2007
(again, no evolution but you can find some papers combining evolution
  & non-linear oscillators).

Last, about commercial/military applications, I'm sure you all have
seen the impressive Big Dog video...

I will present two papers at CEC, we will probably meet there.

Best regards,
--
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
